Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸ“–Â Exploring JavaScript (ES2025 Edition) â€” Dr. Axel is back with his latest book covering all things relating to modern JavaScript at the language level (think built-in data types, modularity, how objects, classes and promises work, etc.). As with all of Axel's books, itâ€™s available to buy but also to read online in HTML form for free. Heâ€™s also produced a set of flashcards to help you learn language features in both HTML and AnkiÂ forms.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ’¡ The two sets of flashcards (including API flashcards) are worth a look on their own as you'll almost certainly learn/remember something useful looking throughÂ them.

How Notion Cut Typing Latency By 15% â€” Stop guessing why your web app is slow. Paletteâ€™s production JS profiler tells you why, down to the line of code. Get started for freeÂ today.

Palette sponsor

Biome v2: The First Type-Aware Linter That Doesn't Require tsc â€” Boasts being the first JavaScript and TypeScript linter that doesnâ€™t require the TypeScript compiler, while still offering type-aware linting rules. Thereâ€™s a lot to enjoy here, including initial support for linter plugins and improved monorepo support, though note that Vue and Svelte templates arenâ€™t yetÂ supported.

Emanuele Stoppa

IN BRIEF:

  • The Google Chrome team shares an update to the HTML specification around the escaping of < and > in HTMLÂ attributes.

  • Collaborative design tool company Figma has acquired Payload, creators of the popular eponymous open source Next.js backendÂ framework/CMS.

  • ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± Vite's official conference, ViteConf, takes place this October 9-10 in Amsterdam. Its CFP is open till JulyÂ 1.

  • JSON module scripts are now Baseline 'Newly Available'.

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.2.16 â€“ The high performance JS runtime adds support for returning files for routes via Bun.serve, along with a slew of bugfixes and Node compatibilityÂ improvements.

  • Astro 5.10 â€“ The content-driven JS framework makes its responsive images feature stable, and adds a new experimental feature: live contentÂ collections.

  • ESLint v9.29.0 â€“ Now supports the syntax used for explicit resource management (using and awaitÂ using).

  • Hono 4.8, Relay v20, Fastify 5.4, NeutralinoJS 6.1, Axios 1.10.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â–¶Â Â Compiling JavaScript Ahead-of-Time â€” The creator of the Porffor JavaScript compiler talks about the various ways to make JavaScript faster to execute, before digging into Porfforâ€™sÂ approach.

Oliver Medhurst

Using await at the Top Level in ES Modules â€” Top-level await is supported in all modern browsers and in Node.js (beyond v16) in .mjs files or .js files specified asÂ modules.

Matt Smith

Clerk OAuth Gets a Big Upgrade â€” Now Fully MCP-Ready â€” Clerk OAuth now supports token revocation, consent screens, dynamic clients, & moreâ€”now fully MCP-ready. Learn moreÂ here.

Clerk sponsor

JavaScript Broke the Web (and Called It Progress) â€” An esteemed SEO consultant shares his thoughts on the complexity of the modern Web and JavaScriptâ€™s role inÂ particular.

Jono Alderson

How TypeScript Solved Its Global Iterator Name Clash â€” ES2025 adds an Iterator class containing iterator helper methods. However, this class conflicts with TypeScriptâ€™s existing types forÂ iterators..

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ 'How Cursor Upgraded Our Storybook in Just 2 Hours' â€“ If youâ€™re going to use AI, it might as well be to speed up boringÂ tasks. Uri Klar

ğŸ“„ Coding a 3D Audio Visualizer with Three.js, GSAP and Web Audio API Filip Zrnzevic

ğŸ“„ Bringing React's <ViewTransition> to Vanilla JS Joeri Sebrechts

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

<syntax-highlight>: A Custom Element for Syntax Highlighting â€” A custom element that uses the CSS Custom Highlight API (supported by most modern browsers) for syntax highlighting so you donâ€™t need to retreat to the age-old method of wrapping every token in spans. GitHubÂ repo.

AndrÃ© Ruffert

React Native 0.80 Released â€” React Native 0.80 lands with React 19.1, a new opt-in set of stricter TypeScript types, and experimental support for prebuilt dependencies on iOS to speed up builds. The legacy architecture is now officially 'frozen', with warnings for APIs slated for futureÂ removal.

Cohen, Cucci, Dall'Agnol, and Falch

Handsontable: Spreadsheet-Like JavaScript Data Grid for Your App â€” Feature-rich data grid for developers seeking a powerful, customizable, and accessible solution to manage complexÂ data.

Handsontable sponsor

react-searchable-dropdown: A Customizable Dropdown Component â€” A modern, accessible, and customizable dropdown component that supports large datasets with virtualization, lets users create new options, works with both simple and complex data, and is easy to style and extend. GitHubÂ repo.

Lucio D'Alessandro

WelsonJS: Build Windows Apps Using Windows' Built-In JS Engine â€” WelsonJS = Windows + Electron-like + JS. Optimized for environments with limited computingÂ power.

Go Namhyeon

  • MockRTC 0.5 â€“ Intercept, assert on and mock WebRTCÂ peers.

  • State in URL 5.0 â€“ Store any user state in query parameters. v5 adds Remix support, but it also supports Next.js and ReactÂ Router.

  • LogTape 0.12 â€“ Logging library for JavaScript and TypeScript with zero dependencies and support for multipleÂ environments.

  • ğŸ“Š Ant Design Charts 2.4 â€“ React chart library. Demos and codeÂ samples.

  • ğŸ“Š Chart.js 4.5 â€“ Simple Canvas-based charting. (Samples.)

  • tiff 7.0 â€“ Pure JS TIFF image decodingÂ library.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸš€ Build VueJS forms your way with Enforma â€” UI-agnostic (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Quasar), schema-ready, repeatable fields, powerfulÂ validation.

ğŸ¤ First speakers at JSNation US: Addy Osmani, Scott Tolinski, Ryan Carniato & more! Nov 17 & 20 in NYC & online. Early Bird goingÂ fast!

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere...

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • The creators of the CKEditor JavaScript rich-text editor explain, in depth, how they made their editor's bundle 40% smaller.

  • Ernie Smith tells the story of why JPEGs still rule the Web.

  • ğŸ¤– Cloudflare has unveiled a way to connect any React app to an MCP server in just three lines of code, using its use-mcp hook.

  • Microsoft recently released a new VS Code extension for working with Postgres. There's now also â–¶ï¸ a presentation showing off how it can be used.

  • Git 2.50.0 has been released and it's quite a significant release. GitHub also rounded up some of what'sÂ new.

  • A thorough tutorial to using and creating Makefiles.

item.title: ã€Say hello to ECMAScript 2025ã€‘ä½ å¥½ ECMAScript 2025
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹742 â€” June 27, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2025: Whatâ€™s New? â€” Itâ€™s that time of year again. The Ecma General Assembly has approved the ES2025 language specification, which you can read in full here if you have a gallon of coffee to hand â€” or you can enjoy Dr. Axelâ€™s more succinct explainerÂ instead.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

What's Coming to JavaScript â€” The ES2025 spec is great, but what else is coming down the pike? The Deno team has put together a look, complete with code samples, at nine proposals progressing through TC39â€™s process rightÂ now.

Casonato and Jiang (Deno)

Fullstack without Frameworks â€” Maximiliano Firtman combines vanilla JavaScript and Go to create high-performance apps from scratch. Follow along in this video course and learn more about web components, dynamic client-side routing, authentication, logging and everything inÂ between.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Vite 7.0 Released â€” At five years old, Vite has radically changed the frontend building experience and is an essential tool for many. v7 is an evolutionary step more than a revolutionary one and should prove an easy upgrade fromÂ v6.

VoidZero Inc.

IN BRIEF:

  • The speaker lineup for JSConf 2025 has been announced. It takes place in Maryland thisÂ October.

  • If you love the V8 team's deep dives, they have a new one looking at two new optimizations introduced into V8 for speeding up WebAssembly.

  • Shopify's William Candillon reflects on the future of advanced graphics in React Native using React Native Skia, and how WebGPU, Three.js, and a new backend called Skia Graphite are changing theÂ game.

  • The popular and long standing Construct HTML5 + JavaScript game development environment now has full built-in support for TypeScript too.

  • The Angular team has created a set of LLM prompts and AI IDE rules files to help Angular developers get better code out ofÂ LLMs.

  • Vercel hosted its annual Vercel Ship event this week and they made so many announcements, you'll need this recap post to get through themÂ all.

  • ğŸ•’ The Temporal API proposal is now a Stage 3Â Draft.

RELEASES:

  • Transformers.js 3.6 â€“ Run machine learning models in the browser, Node, Deno & Bun. Now supporting Gemma 3n (though not in-browser yet).

  • zx 8.6 â€“ Google's tool for better Node shellÂ scripting.

  • Node.js v22.17.0 (LTS), v24.3.0 (Current) and v20.19.3 (LTS)

  • Prettier 3.6, Bun v1.2.17, SVGO 4.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Tips for Making Regular Expressions Easier to Use in JavaScript â€” Dr. Axel asks us to imagine if we had to write JavaScript without any whitespace or comments, so why should we have to write regexes that way? He has some tips for making the process moreÂ pleasant.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Creating a Simple RSS Server Side Reader â€” Alex likes that blogs have feeds, but isnâ€™t so keen on modern feed readers, so he put together a surprisingly simple Deno-based approach to scrape feeds and produce an automatically updated HTML page linking to the latestÂ items.

Alex Kladov

How OAuth Works â€” A practical guide to OAuth Scoped Access with code examples, security tips, and how third-party integrations reallyÂ work.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ“„ Implementing an Undo/Redo System in a Complex Visual Application mlacast

ğŸ“„ No Time To Learn (Web) Framework X â€“ How can you judge when itâ€™s worth the time to learn somethingÂ new? Wouter Groeneveld

ğŸ“„ Comparing Rust, JavaScript and Go for Authoring WASM Components Obelisk

ğŸ“„ How to Write Compelling Software Release Announcements Michael Lynch

ğŸ“º Generating Playwright Tests with AI: Let's Try the New Playwright MCP Server Stefan Judis

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Hono 4.8: A Cross-Runtime Standards-Oriented Web Framework â€” Hono is a framework well worth exploring. Itâ€™s fast, lightweight, built on Web Standards, and can be used to build apps that work on numerous platforms from Node or Bun to Cloudflare or Fastly. v4.8 adds new route helper functions, improvements to JSX streaming and CORS, a new plugin system for static site generation, andÂ more.

Yusuke Wada and Contributors

LogTape 1.0.0: Universal Logging for JavaScript Apps â€” Whether itâ€™s in Node, the browser, or edge functions, LogTape is here for you. Itâ€™s particularly aimed at library developers who want to add logging in a low hassle way for end users â€“ learn moreÂ here.

Hong Minhee

ğŸ’¡ If you want the full sales pitch, Hong Minhee explains why you'll (probably) love LogTape if you're a JavaScript libraryÂ builder.

ğŸ¤–Â Google Unveils Gemini CLI: An Open-Source AI Agent â€” Google has dipped its toe into the rapidly growing AI dev agent game with a terminal-based agent, built in TypeScript, with a striking high free usage allowance, making it a good way to give such tools a try if you havenâ€™t soÂ far.

Mullen and Salva (Google)

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸš€ Build VueJS forms your way with Enforma â€” UI-agnostic (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Quasar), schema-ready, repeatable fields, powerfulÂ validation.

ğŸª Learn from Bun & SolidJS creators, Syntax.fm co-host & more JS stars at the Westâ€™s biggest planetarium! See you Nov 17â€“20 in NYC &Â online.

PLJS 1.0: JavaScript Language Plugin for Postgres â€” PLV8 has been the â€˜go toâ€™ way to use JavaScript as a procedural language within Postgres for years, but this QuickJS-based variant, from the same maintainer, has a far lighter footprint, is easier to maintain, and may be enough for yourÂ needs.

Jerry Sievert

Marked 16.0: A Fast Markdown Parser and Compiler â€” Demo here to see it in action. GitHubÂ repo.

Christopher Jeffrey

Vue Infinity: Virtualized Rendering for Large Datasets â€” The idea is simple: if itâ€™s not visible, it doesnâ€™t get rendered. A handy way to keep things fast when dealing with large feeds, carousels, dashboards, etc. GitHubÂ repo.

Isaac Tewolde

Spark: Advanced 3D Gaussian Splatting Renderer for Three.js â€” Check out the liveÂ examples.

World Labs Technologies, Inc.

  • ğŸ“Š Billboard.js 3.16.0 â€“ The popular chart library adds 'trending lines' to bar charts, perf improvements, and other tweaks.

  • Hako 1.0 â€“ An embeddable, lightweight, high-performance JavaScript engine built atopÂ QuickJS.

  • React Admin 5.9 â€“ Framework for building B2B frontendÂ interfaces.

  • ğŸ“Š AG Charts 12.0 â€“ Full-featured, customizable chartingÂ library.

  • ğŸ“ˆ Recharts 3.0 â€“ D3-powered chart library forÂ React.

ğŸÂ A few bonus items..

Just some things I've seen that didn't fit anywhere else, but I wanted to give a quickÂ mention:

  • ğŸ¤– Google has released Gemma 3n, its latest locally-runnable LLM. It performs very well for its size (5B and 8B parameterÂ counts) and if you've got the right hardware, you can run it easily with Ollama and similar tools.

  • Coder extraordinare Bisqwit is back from a long hiatus with â–¶ï¸Â a video on cracking game passwords in 1980s NES games.

  • David Heinemeier Hansson, of Ruby on Rails fame, has released Omarchy â€“ an 'opinionated Arch/Hyprland setup' to get Linux working in an aesthetically pleasing way for software developers, whether using Ruby orÂ not.

  • A notably buff John Carmack recently gave a talk (complete with his first slide deck ever) about â–¶ï¸Â his team's work and research directions around machine learning, multi-task learning, and getting AI to play AtariÂ games.

  • How to disable zsh history for a given shell session â€“ a handyÂ trick.

P.S. Yes, I actually wrote with a sharpie on my bookshelf for today's header graphic and it doesn't come off so easily. But it was worthÂ it.

#â€‹744 â€” July 11, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Vercel Acquires NuxtLabs â€” Vercel has acquired the company that caretakes the Nuxt project and employs some of its core team â€“ a move Vue creator Evan You is quite optimistic about. Vercel now manages, or at least supports, several key projects like Next.js, Turborepo, Svelte, and shadcn/ui. Nuxt itself remains open source and has a promising future. Vercelâ€™s Guillermo Rauch shares a little more about the moveÂ here.

NuxtLabs / Vercel

ğŸ’¡ Daniel Roe, leader of the Nuxt team, answered lots of questions about the acquisition onÂ Reddit.

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript Datagrid â€” A fast and flexible DataGrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the core grid module. Pick & choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, andÂ Vue.

Wijmo From MESCIUS sponsor

A Detailed Summary of the Latest TC39 Plenary â€” A thorough roundup of Mayâ€™s major ECMAScript committee meeting with far more detail about each proposalâ€™s development and the decisions made than we usually get to hear about. Topics include Array.fromAsync, explicit resource management, the Temporal API, and some brainstorming aroundÂ AsyncContext.

Igalia Compilers Team

IN BRIEF:

  • TypeScript 5.9 Beta has been released with support for deferred module evaluation by using import defer.

  • The Nginx HTTP server has a module (njs) for extending its functionality using JavaScript, but it only supported ES5. Now, njs uses QuickJS for a more modern, powerful experience with full ES2023Â support.

  • Got some time to kill? There's one week left to submit an entry to the JS1024 annual JavaScript golfing competition. Create a cool JS or GLSL program in under 1024 bytes.

  • Oliver Stenbom reflects on the prevalence of Rust in modern JavaScript ecosystem tooling.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v24.4.0 (Current) â€“ Note that new versions of all maintained Node.js releases are due next week due to some securityÂ vulnerabilities.

  • Oxlint 1.6 â€“ Rust-powered linter for JS andÂ TS.

  • VS Code v1.102, Ember 6.5, Angular 20.1

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Whatâ€™s the Difference Between Ordinary Functions and Arrow Functions? â€” This sounds like basic stuff, but James always does a good job of digging in and explaining things in a way that gives you a more nuanced way to think about a concept, even if itâ€™s just â€œWhich function declaration syntax should IÂ use?â€

James Sinclair

ğŸ’¡ His guide to how to compose JS functions that take multiple parameters is also worthÂ revisiting.

Embrace Web RUM Provides User-Focused Observability â€” Get session timelines, Core Web Vitals and JS exceptions in context, and user journey analysis with issueÂ correlation.

Embrace sponsor

JavaScript Scope Hoisting is Broken â€” The creator of Parcel argues that scope hoisting (when bundlers inline modules into a shared scope) conflicts with modern JS patterns like code splitting and dynamic imports, causing subtle bugs and offering little benefit, so heâ€™s considering removing it in ParcelÂ v3.

Devon Govett

Codepointâ€“Safe Truncation: Fixing Emoji Slicing â€” An appâ€™s CSV importer kept breaking on emoji-filled rows, triggering errors. James demonstrates how swapping slice for a code-pointâ€“aware spread fixesÂ it.

James Mulholland

ğŸ“„ Parsing 1 Billion Rows in Bun in Under 10 Seconds Tae Kim

ğŸ“„ Loosely Synchronize Your JS Stores in Multiple Tauri Processes â€“ Tauri is a bit like a Rust-flavored Electron for building cross-platform nativeÂ apps. Costa Alexoglou

ğŸ“„ Managing the State of Your Promises â€“ On the potential of Promise.all and Promise.allSettled. Lydia Cho

ğŸ“„ When Can I Use Temporal? â€“ â€œIf Brendan Eich can invent .. JavaScript in 10 days, why has it taken eight years to replace the DateÂ API?â€ John Dalziel

ğŸ“„ Is It Still Worth Using jQuery in 2025? Suren Enfiajyan

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Driver.js: Tours, Highlights, Contextual Help, and More â€” A vanilla JS library for making on-page tours and contextual help systems. Itâ€™s been around for several years, but is still maintained, and there are lots of examples to check out â€“ itâ€™s reallyÂ smooth.

Kamran Ahmed

jsonrepair: Repair Invalid JSON Documents â€” This has lots of possible use cases, including dealing with weird JSON coming back from LLMs or non-compliant JSON spat out by poorly built software. You can use it from Node, as a CLI tool, or try a basic versionÂ online.

Jos de Jong

ğŸ¤¡ In barely related news, someone has turned JSON into its own programming language. Oh, theÂ horror!

Server-Side Support for MCP in Next.js â€” Server-side MCP just got easier in Next.js. One route, no extra infraâ€”Scorecard cut 1,000 lines to justÂ 70.

Clerk sponsor

line-numbers: A Web Component to Add Line Numbers Next to Various HTML Elements â€” Useful for custom apps that show source code or other snippets that require line numbering. See examples here, which demonstrate the flexibility customization options for the lineÂ numbering.

Zach Leatherman

cRonstrue 3.0: Convert Cron Expressions into Natural Language â€” Not just English either - it supports about thirty locales. Thereâ€™s also an onlineÂ demo.

Brady Holt

  • Next.js Boilerplate 5.0 â€“ Boilerplate starter app for Next.js with auth, database support, i18n, forms, andÂ more.

  • ğŸ” React Scan 0.4 â€“ Scan for performance issues and eliminate slow renders in yourÂ app.

  • ğŸ¹ html-midi-player 1.6 â€“ Play and display MIDI files on the web.

  • CKEditor5 46.0 â€“ Popular commercial rich text editor framework.

  • ğŸ“Š Recharts 3.1 â€“ D3-powered chart library forÂ React.

  • Vuetify 3.9 â€“ Vue componentÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ“Œ Try out PinMe: free CLI tool helps deploy your static site in secondsâ€”and keeps it online without any ongoing cost orÂ maintenance.

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere...

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • As of Chrome 137, you can try out CSS inline conditionals using the new if() function.

  • Did you know you can generate efficient SVGs that feel like GIFs and even use them in your GitHub README.md files?

  • On Reddit, an ex-Meta engineer posted an interesting comment about how Meta / Facebook serves up React as part of the main FacebookÂ site.

  • PlanetScale has shared a neat interactive article about caching that visually demonstrates the benefits of caching from several different angles, right down to the CPU level.

  • ğ• Claude Code is now a single-file executable thanks to Bun.

  • ANSI.tools is a handy online tool for analyzing ANSI escape codes/sequences and a lookup of common codes.

item.title: ã€The dog days of JavaScript summerã€‘The dog days of JavaScript summer
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹743 â€” July 4, 2025

Read on the Web

ğŸ–Šï¸ Itâ€™s been a quiet week with heatwaves and holidays seeming to slow the usual flow, but we've made it.. thanks to a few items out of left field ğŸ˜… For our US readers, happy Independence Day!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

â˜€ï¸ JavaScript Weekly â˜€ï¸

Deno 2.4: deno bundle is Back â€” Deno 2.4 reintroduces the deno bundle command for creating single-file bundles for both the server and client side, complete with support for npm and JSR dependencies and automatic tree-shaking. You can also now include arbitrary files into modules using import, and Denoâ€™s built-in OpenTelemetry support is now stable. Itâ€™s a substantialÂ release.

IwaÅ„czuk and Jiang

ğŸ’¡ Not to play favorites, Bun v1.2.18 is now out too.

CodeRabbitâ€™s Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf â€” Code Rabbit brings AI code reviews to VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf. Get line-by-line reviews, one-click fixes & codebase-aware feedback - all free in your IDE. Seamlessly integrates with git workflows. Install the extension & startÂ reviewing!

CodeRabbit sponsor

What's New in ECMAScript 2025: Another Take â€” Last week we featured Dr. Axelâ€™s look at whatâ€™s new in ES2025, but PaweÅ‚ has another example-led take here that you mightÂ enjoy.

PaweÅ‚ Grzybek

IN BRIEF:

  • âš–ï¸ Ryan Dahl has an update on the ongoing JavaScriptâ„¢ trademark dispute. Oracle has about a month to respond in full to Deno's cancellationÂ petition.

  • JS1024 is an annual JavaScript code golfing contest. You've got till July 19 to submit a JavaScript program written in 1024 bytes or less on the theme ofÂ 'Creepy'.

  • Today's the final day you can vote for an official Angular mascot.

  • In other Angular news, there's now a new way to track Angular-specific data in Chrome DevTools.

  • Microsoft has open-sourced its GitHub Copilot Chat extension for VS Code. Even if you have no interest in AI, it offers a good look at how MS builds its ownÂ extensions.

RELEASES:

  • Rspack 1.4 â€“ Fast Rust-based (and webpack compatible) web bundler. v1.4 can now run in the browser, too, thanks toÂ WebAssembly.

  • Electron 37.0 â€“ The cross-platform desktop app toolkit.

  • ESLint 9.30.0 and 9.30.1

  • Astro 5.11, Babel 7.28.0, Three.js r178

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

How to Build Your Own Color Search Engine â€” A straightforward, practical look at bringing together several technologies and skills to create an AI powered color suggestion tool (which you can try here â€“ results may vary, as seen above). The techniques covered can be used for many different practicalÂ ends.

LÃºÃ­ Smyth

Building a Lightweight Reactive State Manager with JavaScript Proxies â€” What if you didnâ€™t need a library for reactive state mangement? What if you could build a system thatâ€™s powerful and simple using a native JS feature? YouÂ can!

Loren Stewart

The Road to Next â€” Learn full-stack web development with Next.js 15 and React 19. The perfect match for JavaScript developers ready to go beyond theÂ frontend.

Robin Wieruch sponsor

âªÂ A Perplexing JavaScript Parsing Puzzle â€” The most popular item in JavaScript Weekly this year (so far) was simple in presentation but also deceptively simple in what it asked. 14 characters of JS and one straightforward question â€“ can you get it right?

Hillel Wayne

Modern Node.js Patterns for 2025 â€” A reflection on the potential of Node as it stands right now. Ashwin reminds us of various developments, including the use of ES modules, built-in Web APIs, the test runner, watch mode, the permission model, import maps, andÂ more.

Ashwin

ğŸ“„ Transmitting Data via Ultrasound Without Special Equipment â€“ A creative use for JavaScript and the Web AudioÂ API. Lorenz Diener

ğŸ“º What Every React Developer Should Know About Signals Ryan Carniato

ğŸ“„ Custom 3D Models in Mapbox: A Step-by-Step Guide â€“ Niche, but potentially veryÂ useful. Mykola Chernyshevskyi

ğŸ“„ How JSDoc Saved My Dev Workflow Jordan Booker

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Milkdown: A Plugin-Driven WYSIWYG Markdown Editor Framework â€” A WYSIWYG Markdown editor framework based around a plugin system that enables a significant level of customization. The docs are rendered by Milkdown itself and thereâ€™s a neat â€˜playgroundâ€™ experience to try as well. GitHubÂ repo.

Mirone

Repomix 1.0: Pack a Codebase Into an AI-Friendly Format â€” Enter a GitHub URL, choose your settings (XML, MD, etc), and get a blob that's ideal if you want an LLM to answer questions about or analyze that repo. You can use it online or as a library in Node. GitHubÂ repo.

Kazuki Yamada

You Can Now Run Playwright Tests on Real iOS Devices with Safari â€” Spot iOS-specific issues by testing web apps on real iPhones & iPads, with logs, video playback & true SafariÂ rendering.

BrowserStack sponsor

snapDOM 1.8: Captures DOM Nodes as Images â€” A rapidly maturing, fast and accurate DOM-to-image capture mechanism to capture any HTML element as a scalable SVG image, preserving styles, fonts, background images, etc. The homepage is packed withÂ examples.

ZumerLab

ğŸ—“ï¸Â Time Picker: A shadcn/ui-Based Date/Time Picker Component â€” Simple, elegant, and feels good toÂ use.

OpenStatus

ğŸ¨Â Spectral.js: A 'Paint-Like' Color Mixing Library â€” If you have two colors to transition between, tweening the RGB values can result in some ugly intermediate colors. Spectral.js uses Kubelkaâ€“Munk theory which more closely matches how paints work for a visually satisfyingÂ result.

Ronald van Wijnen

  • Protobuf-ES 2.6 â€“ Full Protocol Buffers implementation forÂ JS/TS.

  • â™Ÿï¸ React Chessboard 5.0 â€“ Render chess boards withÂ React. (Examples.)

  • Faker 9.9 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • jQuery Terminal Emulator 2.45 â€“ Create web-based terminal experiences.Â (Demo.)

  • iCal.js 2.2 â€“ Parser for ICS (RFC5545) and vCardÂ (RFC6350).

  • NG-MATERO 20.0 â€“ Angular-based adminÂ template.

  • Mineflayer 4.30 â€“ Create Minecraft bots inÂ JavaScript.

  • css-select 6.0 â€“ CSS selector compiler and engine.

  • Pixi.js 8.11 â€“ Fast, flexible 2D WebGLÂ renderer.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ± ConfigCat Feature Flag Service lets you run gradual rollouts, A/B tests & target users without code changes. Use coupon JAVA25 & saveÂ 25%!

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere...

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • Engineers at Patreon have shared the story of a huge internationalization refactor they've done recently touching over 10,000 JavaScript call sites. I don't envy thisÂ task.

  • If Cloudflare Workers are too limited for your use case, Cloudflare has a new option: Cloudflare Containers. Containers is integrated with Workers but, unsurprisingly, lets you package up your app in container images and run them in a flexibleÂ way.

  • I found the story of how One Million Chessboards, a live, online 1000x1000 grid of chess boards was engineered and scaled to be quiteÂ fascinating.

  • Sharon Brizinov shares the tale of how they tracked down numerous force-pushed 'oops' commits on GitHub and uncovered secrets worth $25k in bug bounties.

  • Popular MySQL cloud provider PlanetScale is entering the Postgres space. It's in 'private preview' but they've already teased someÂ benchmarks.

  • ğŸµ If you fancy getting creative, Strudel is a neat way to code music in the browser. There's a lot to enjoy here with live examples throughout theÂ docs.
